speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 10-1104, Minneci v. Pollard. Mr. Franklin.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We go back to what you said initially; that is, if there's no alternative remedy, Bivens fills the gap. Suppose we had a case just like Carlson, only the State law allows survivor actions.  In Carlson, I thought the rule emerging from Carlson is that prison personnel in Federal prisons are subject to Bivens liability, and we don't look in each case to see whether there could have been a State tort.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is that so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, suppose, Mr. Franklin, that there weren't.  I mean, I think you have a good case about California law here.  But suppose we were in a State where the law was very different from what California's law appears to be, where there was no special duty recognized for jailors and, indeed, where the basic negligence tort was unavailable to inmates because there was a finding of -- a holding of the State supreme court that there was no duty on the part of jailors to inmates.  What would happen then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But is your answer --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Franklin, there were some references to Mississippi law that seem to be inconsistent with the notion that all States would provide an adequate remedy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is it -- and it might hold State prisoners as well.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It might hold -- some private facilities will take State prisoners as well as Federal prisoners.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And if they do have State prisoners, the State prisoner would have recourse to, not Bivens, but 1983.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, you have two prisoners, identical mistreatment, and one gets a Federal remedy and the other doesn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can you tell me why it is that you care in this suit?  If you're telling us, oh, don't worry, there's going to be liability and probably perhaps even more extensive liability than in Bivens, what difference does it make?  Bivens doesn't give you attorneys' fees.  Now, it's true that the Federal question may get you into Federal court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Just because of the statute of limitations?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If we're looking -- if we're looking forward beyond this case --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- and there's no statute of limitation problem, does it really make any difference that he have this second cause of action that's just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- (a) duplicative or (b) arguably narrow, more narrow?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But why?  What --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What difference does it make?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Who cares?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Franklin --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- do you have a theory about why these are brought as Bivens claims?  It seems mysterious to me.  If you bring it as a negligence claim, you get a lower standard of liability, negligence versus deliberate indifference.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You get vicarious liability. So, I've been trying to puzzle out, why aren't these brought as negligence claims rather than as Bivens claims?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: To go back to what I asked before when I hypothesized a State that didn't have adequate remedies, and you said -- well, just to pin down what you said, if there were no adequate remedies, there would be a Bivens action available?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: To get back to the question that Justice Ginsburg asked, is it -- is that consistent with Carlson?  Because the Court in Carlson didn't say that there's a Bivens action because in this particular State there isn't a viable State action, but it might be different in another State where there is a viable State claim.  It did it on basically a categorical ground.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Does a prisoner in a State that requires the filing of a certificate of merit in a medical malpractice case have a -- have an alternative -- a viable alternative State claim --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- for malpractice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, how is a prisoner supposed to satisfy that requirement?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did any of those courts address the problem of how the pro se prisoner is going to get an affidavit?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't -- I don't understand your answer to Justice Kagan.  If I heard you right, you were saying, well, they're going to be able to get a certificate because it's an Eighth Amendment violation, and everything is very severe.  But the point is they're going to bring a negligence action, not an Eighth Amendment action.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But I think the question, Mr. Franklin, is really just a practical one --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- which is how a pro se person sitting in prison is supposed to have access to a doctor who will provide this certificate.  And, I mean, maybe there would be means, but I guess I'm asking whether there would be.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Under the PLRA -- under the PLRA, a district judge has to perform a screening function for -- for these complaints, and is that -- is it going to be an impossible burden for district judges to ascertain the contours of State prison law, in that there apparently is not a lot of prisoner litigation under State law?  Most prisoners seem to choose 1983.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Shah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Shah, go back to what you said about lacking -- these private -- these employees of the private corporation you said lack qualified immunity.  But they do have -- courts have allowed them to have a good faith defense.  So, in practice, how different is that, whether they have qualified immunity or whether they have a good faith defense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could you address the question posed earlier of what were to happen if there was a State law that gave absolute immunity to these private correctional officers, and that was the case before us.  This particular State, it's undisputed, would not permit any kind of intentional or negligence suit against these officers.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Interesting, because what you're proposing is a sort of State-by-State, circuit-by-circuit, presumably, existence of a Bivens claim or not.  That's really the outcome of your position.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Then I guess the question is -- yes, when you talk about an overlap of remedies, we have said that it doesn't need to be a matching one-to-one remedy, but you do need some degree of meaningful overlap, don't you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, how -- define how much or how do we describe the adequacy of that overlap?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It is -- a Bivens action is unusual in the first place, but it's also unusual to say that you don't have a Federal cause of action because of something a State gives you. Do you have any other example of something like that, where the availability of Federal relief turns on the availability of alternative relief under State law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: What is the theory behind that, Mr. Shah?  I mean it's an obvious theory when Congress has provided an alternative remedial system, which is a separation of powers theory.  But what's the theory about looking to State law for these kinds of alternative remedies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What would you propose that the Court say about the degree of adequate State remedy that is necessary?  Just -- what we have here in California is enough and not go any further or --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Suppose that a State did for claims against private prisons and private prison guards what I understand New York has done with respect to State-run prisons; in other words, that you eliminate any claim against individual prison employees or guards and give the prisoner just a tort claim against the State.  Would that be adequate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Not a claim against the State.  I misspoke.  A claim -- only a claim against the company that runs the prison.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the character of the claim?  If it's a Bivens claim, it's a constitutional claim.  It's an Eighth Amendment claim. And if you're looking to State remedies, that's an ordinary tort remedy with no constitutional involvement.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Preis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why are State remedies -- what of your clients' claims could not be vindicated under State law?  And why is a Bivens action superior to a negligence action in California?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The specific case where the State remedy is not available is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no, no, no.  Your --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Your allegation which you believe states a valid claim under Bivens action but not under State law is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't understand specifically what they are.  I mean, it sounds to me that if a person (a) deliberately starves somebody to death, for example, or deliberately gives him something which will make him sick when he eats it, that that would at least be negligence and would arise under ordinary State tort law.  So, I'm curious to know what your claim is that does not arise under ordinary State tort law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, give me -- don't answer my -- forget my hypothetical.  Tell me your specific claim that does not arise under State tort law.  That's all I want to know.  Which is the same question I heard -- I just didn't hear the answer to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I heard the answer in general.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I want to know specifically what you say they did to your client that doesn't make out a State tort claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I heard you say --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- that.  I just want to know what it is physically you say the defendant did to your client, so that I can evaluate your statement that California gives no tort remedy for that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Sorry, I don't mean to sound irritated, but I just have trouble getting my question across.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  They failed to give him adequate food for what?  So he could live, or for what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They gave him -- and if a person in California who has charge of -- of a ward or someone fails adequately to nourish that ward, you're saying California tort law gives no remedy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I would call it like negligence, you give a remedy.  If it's not negligent, it's deliberate?  Or what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You can't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The lawyer would say, I can't find a starving case in California; so, you must not have a cause of action. Is that what the lawyer would say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It seems odd to me because the Eighth Amendment says cruel and unusual punishment. So, you have to have a cruel treatment.  And where a person deliberately or negligently subjects someone else to cruel treatment, my -- my law school recollection of many years ago is that there ordinarily is a tort action. So, that's what I'd like you -- I'm suspicious of your statement that there isn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Therefore, I ask for some elaboration of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What do you have besides starving?  What -- what else? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Can I ask you the same question that I asked Mr. Franklin?  Because it just doesn't make any sense to me.  The gravamen of this claim is a medical malpractice claim.  Why aren't your State law remedies better?  You have vicarious liability, and all you have to prove is negligence.  Why wasn't this brought as a State law claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, that would be false consciousness that we can correct, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I mean, if the -- if the true appropriate remedy, and the better remedy from your client's point of view, is a State law action, we should just say bring a State law action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: When I went to law school, which was many years ago, instead of talking about, like, starvation cases or medical malpractice, they talked about a general thing called negligence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And it seemed to apply to doctors, and then it was medical malpractice, and it applied to others, and -- and is there something here that wouldn't fall in that general kind of rubric or the general terms of California tort law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And I know, I don't want you just to repeat yourself.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, I guess I have the best answer I have.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- asking us to do is limit our inquiry to California?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Limit it to California. What -- what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: They're saying don't look at what other courts will do; just look at the State you're in, the place you're going to make your claim, and figure out whether your claims are covered or not covered essentially in those -- in that State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, so, if there is one State that would not have an adequate remedy for any -- any single bad thing that could happen in prison, there's a Bivens action for everybody for everything? Is that what you're saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Wow.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I certainly wouldn't want to hold that. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I would find that rather surprising, too, actually. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because I -- I think what they're asking to do is fine.  On their theory, you have no problem because you go back and show to the court that there is no remedy in California for shackling a person, I guess, deliberately, with knowledge that that would cause severe pain, and if you can show that, then you're going to have your Bivens action in respect to that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That -- what they're saying is that you're not going to be able to show that; so, it doesn't worry them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who says that the burden is on the other side?  Why isn't the burden on you, if you want to bring a Bivens action, on you, to show that there is not an adequate State remedy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're the plaintiff here. You're trying to bring the Federal cause of action.  Our law is clear; if there's an adequate remedy we don't invent one.  Why isn't it your burden to show that there is not an adequate State remedy?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, before you do, on page 5 of your brief you say, in the private prison setting, quote, "'a Bivens claim against the offending individual offending officer,'" end quote, is an appropriate remedy.  And the quote is from Malesko.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What we said in Malesko, where you quote, is that if a Federal prisoner in a BOP facility alleges a constitutional deprivation, he may bring a Bivens claim against the offending individual officer.  Now, your friend describes that as a distortion of what we said in Malesko, and I just wanted to give you a chance to reply to what I think is a fairly serious assertion.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, just to be clear, you quote that language -- you say "in the private prison setting"; and the language specifically says in a BOP facility.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You would expect the same rule.  That's your argument --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- to apply in the private prison setting.  What you say is that there we explained that, in the private prison setting, a Bivens claim against the offending individual officer was the appropriate remedy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's known as misquoting.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Would you be taking the position that even if there is an alternative State remedy, tort remedy, even so there ought to be a parallel Bivens action?  Or would you say no Bivens action if all of the States have adequate tort remedies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Could you give me your best example of a State tort rule that would prevent a prisoner from bringing an Eighth Amendment claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Your best example of a tort rule from any State that would preclude a -- a valid Eighth Amendment claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You have 50 States' worth of tort law to -- as your playground, and I want to know what tort rule would keep a prisoner with a valid Eighth Amendment claim -- would prevent him from recovering?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand what you're talking about.  Is this a suit against a prisoner who was attacked?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He's not liable unless he's malicious, or what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The warden.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I see.  And -- and the warden is liable in Maryland, you say, only if he is malicious?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What about medical malpractice caps?  Is that an issue?  In other words, State law -- and I don't know how many there are; I know it's been proposed -- I think it's true in some cases will cap your recovery for medical malpractice at a particular level.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I was -- that was a helpful question, in the sense that -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The Bivens action -- presumably the cap would not apply.  But it applies under State law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But in Carlson, it was Bivens or no damage remedy.  Here, that's not the case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In Carlson, the Court was operating on the theory that with respect to the Federal employee, it was a Bivens remedy for damages or no remedy at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And here, it is different from Carlson because there is an -- a remedy against an individual.  So, we have the parallel remedies here which didn't exist in Carlson, and that makes the two cases different.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you disagree that the -- I know you have your argument on compensation --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- but with respect to deterrence, is there any significant difference between the two causes of action?  In other words, if you think the most significant aspect of Bivens is to deter constitutional violations, doesn't that work equally as well or perhaps more effectively under the State law than under Bivens?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, your answer -- your answer is the same as under compensation, that the State law might be different or not?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Who -- who actually ends up paying in these Bivens actions?  Is it the -- I mean --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- the Federal Government or an individual or --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm just looking in terms of the practical deterrence.  The problem I've had with it in general, I don't know how much practical deterrence there is as if you sue the individual and the -- the individual doesn't actually pay; the government does.  It seems to me perhaps more likely in the private context that the individual may get stuck with some amount of the liability if the employer just says, look, you were off doing something you weren't supposed to do; we're not going to pay for it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think that the warden of a Maryland prison is aware that if -- if he allows one prisoner to beat up another prisoner, he is only liable for maliciousness and not for deliberate indifference, if indeed there is a difference between the two?  Do you think that -- that he's threading the needle that finely, as far as -- as far as deterrence is concerned?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not at that level of -- of refinement.  I mean, it seems to me that any warden knows he's subject to State tort law and that State tort law renders him liable for negligence and, indeed, for physical assaults.  Some of your causes of action are intentional torts, not even negligence.  I find it hard to believe that, as far as deterrence is concerned, there's a dime's worth of difference between State law and -- and the Bivens action you're asking for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, what was the purpose of making the reference to private contractors in the Westfall Act?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Franklin, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you want us to hold that there's no Bivens action in California?  Is that -- is that what our opinion is going to say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do you know if any of these Bivens claims have been pled in the alternative; that is, a Bivens remedy, but alternatively State law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is there diversity in this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, you said there was a statute of limitations problem with starting new.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about, if there is diversity --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- allowing an amendment?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
